Take-Home Exercise 1: Application of Spatial and Spatio-temporal Point Patterns Analysis to discover the geographical distribution of Armed Conflict in Myanmar

Author

William

Published

September 7, 2024

Modified

September 8, 2024

Objectives

I will be using armed conflict data of Myanmar from January 2021 to June 2024, aka Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED).

I will be focusing on thsese main event types:

  • Battles,

  • Explosion/Remote violence,

  • Strategic developments, and

  • Violence against civilians.

Data

Packages

These R packages will be used:

  • sf: importing, managing, and processing geospatial data, and

  • tidyverse: performing data science tasks such as importing, wrangling and visualising data.

  • readr

    • read_csv(): reading ACLED csv data

  • janitor: data cleaning

  • Extra (TBD):

    • lubridate - to format dates

    • cowplot - add-on to ggplot for higher quality figures

    • htmlwidgets for R - interactive visualisations (could be used for visual analytics)

      • leaflet - geo-spatial mapping
pacman:::p_load(sf,tidyverse,janitor) # more to be added

Load the ACLED

acled <- read_csv('data/2021-01-01-2024-07-01-Myanmar.csv')

Metadata

Click to expand â€“>
Variable Description
â€˜event_id_cntyâ€™ unique alphanumeric ID by number & country acronym
â€˜event_dateâ€™ day-month-year of event
â€˜yearâ€™ self-explanatory
â€˜time_precisonâ€™ numeric code for level of precison of data records
â€˜disorder_typeâ€™ i.e. â€˜Demonstrationsâ€™,â€˜Political violenceâ€™,â€˜Political violence; Demonstrationsâ€™,â€˜Strategic developmentsâ€™
â€˜event_typeâ€™ nature of event
â€˜sub_event_typeâ€™ provides further classification to event_type

â€˜actor1â€™

â€˜assoc_actor_1â€™

â€˜actor2â€™

â€˜assoc_actor_2â€™

 involved actors along with their respective affiliates

â€˜inter1â€™

â€˜inter2â€™

 numeric code between 0 and 8 encoding different actors
â€˜interactionâ€™ indicates the 2 actor types interacting in the event (using inter1 & inter2 codes)
â€˜civilian_targetingâ€™ indicates whether the event involved civilian targeting (e.g. null if false)
â€˜isoâ€™ unique 3-digit numeric code assigned to each country or territory according to ISO 3166
â€˜regionâ€™ region of the world where the event took place
â€˜countryâ€™ self-explanatory

â€˜admin1â€™

â€˜admin2â€™

â€˜admin3â€™

 national administrative regions where the event took place (admin1 being the largest)
â€˜locationâ€™ self-explanatory
â€˜latitudeâ€™ self-explanatory
â€˜longitudeâ€™ self-explanatory
â€˜geo_precisionâ€™ numeric code for level of precison of event location
â€˜sourceâ€™ source of event report
â€˜source_scaleâ€™ scale (e.g. local, international) of the source
â€˜notesâ€™ description of the event
â€˜fatalitiesâ€™ number of reported fatalities in the event
â€˜tagsâ€™ targets (type and estimate counts)
â€˜timeâ€™ Unix Timestamp of event

Data Wrangling

In this section, I will be doing basic data cleaning and formatting across the ACLED columns so that I can derive appropriate variables needed for analysis.

Check for missing data

sum(is.na(acled))
[1] 179468

Clearly, this doesnâ€™t provide much insight to the state of the ACLED columns. Hence I consulted Uncle Google for some alternatives:

  • base R functions:
# Count missing values in each column
missing_counts <- lapply(acled, function(x) sum(is.na(x)))

# Print the results
missing_counts

For fun, hereâ€™s other methods:

  • R package janitor, summarise() and across()

    # Summarize missing values in each column
acled %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), ~ sum(is.na(.)))) %>%
  janitor::adorn_totals("row")
     event_id_cnty event_date year time_precision disorder_type event_type

         Total          0    0              0             0          0
